lg.l: SIreF.7.1: The ornamented capital is red with green flourishing which extends about half way down the page. wit / hadde a wif / was klepid dame stodye.F.7.1: A red VII with red flourishes appears in the top right corner of this badly cropped leaf to indicate the passus number.
Ãat leene was of leere / & of lycame boÃ¾e.
She was wondirful wroÃ¾F.7.3: The <r> is a correction supplied by the original scribe over an illegible character. / Ã¾at wit me tawhte.F.7.3: The <a> has an otiose curl above it.
& al sterne starynge / & startlyngeF.7.4: startlynge, "leaping, jumping." she seyde.
Wel art Ã¾ou wyÈs quod she / ony wisdom to telle.
To flatereris & folis / Ã¾at feble are of wittys.
& blamed hym bustously / & bad hym be stylle.
With swiche wise wordis / to wissyn ony sottys.
& seyÈde man / noli mittere / Margerye perlys.
By-fore hoggis Ã¾at hetyn hawis / at hoom at here wille.
Ãey don but dravele Ã¾ere-on / draf were hem bettre.
Ãan al Ã¾e precious perre / Ã¾at in paradyÈs wexeÃ¾.
I sey it / be swiche quod she / Ã¾at shewe be here werkys.

Ãat hem were leuere lond / & lordshepe here.F.7.14: Alpha is responsible for the defective b-verse; beta witnesses read "and lordshipe on erÃ¾e." F then omits the following line from Bx: "Or richesse or rentes and reste at hir wille." Cf. 5.1180 where F alone substitutes here for on Ã¾is erÃ¾e.
Ãan alle Ã¾e soÃ¾e sawis / Ã¾at salomon seyde euere.
For now wit & wisdom / ys not worÃ¾ a kerse
But it be Cardyd with coueytise / as kytte kembeÃ¾ wolle.
Who can contrive deseytys / & conspyren wrongys.

& ledyn forÃ¾ a loveday / &F.7.19: Alpha is responsible for &. Beta manuscripts and the A text have to. lettyn euere trewthe.F.7.19: F omits through eye-skip on truÃ¾e the following lines from Bx:
He Ã¾at swiche craftes kan to counseil is cleped
Thei lede lordes wiÃ¾ lesynges and belieÃ¾ truÃ¾e.
Â¶ Ioob Ã¾at ys so Ientyl / in his Iestys tellyÃ¾.
Ãat wikkede men welden / welthys on moolde.
& Ã¾ey Ã¾at ben lordis of leedis / as owtlawys Ã¾ei lybbe.
& owt of oure Lordis lawe / Ã¾at leneÃ¾ hem Ã¾at welthe. These lines appear only in F.
& Ã¾ynke not who it oweÃ¾ / Ã¾at Ã¾ei wasten heere.

hi.hi: Quare ergo Impij viuunt sulleuati sunt diuicijs.

l.note: F.7.25: F has changed the Latin text, quoting more of Job 21:7 than appears in the archetype and ignoring Bx's conflation of the passage from Job with Jeremiah 12:1. Bx reads as follows: "Quare impij viuunt? Bene est omnibus qui preuaricantur & inique agunt?"

lg.l: Â¶ The sawter seyÃ¾ Ã¾e same / be swiche Ã¾at doon Ille.

hi.hi: Ecce ipsi peccatores habundantes in seculo

l.note: F.7.27: F abbreviates the Latin quotation, omitting obtinuerunt diuicias. Alpha is responsible for the omission of diuicias.

lg.l: Loo ï ¡ seyÃ¾ holy lettrure / wiche lordis be Ã¾ese shrewis.

Ão Ã¾at god moost greve mest good he hem deleÃ¾.F.7.29: A space was left for a medial solidus after greve, but it was not written. F's gap may indicate some other dissatisfaction with his exemplar, for his line is unique. Bx probably reads "Thilke Ã¾at god moost gyueÃ¾ leest good Ã¾ei deleÃ¾," though manuscript C agrees with alpha in reading "most greueth" in place of "moost gyueÃ¾."
& most vnkynde to Ã¾e comoun be / hem moost catel sendiÃ¾

hi.hi: Qve perfecisti destruxerunt . Iustus autem.

lg.l: Â¶ Harlotis for here harlotryÈe / shulle have here goodis
As Iaperis & Iogeloures / & Iangleres of Iestys.
Â¶ But he Ã¾at haÃ¾ holy wryt / ay in his mowthe.
& can tellyn of Tobye / & of Ã¾e xije apostlys.
Or prechen of Ã¾e penaunce / Ã¾at Pilat to crist wrouhte.
Or of Ientil Iesu / Ã¾at Iewis dyde on roode.
He is lytyl lovid now / Ã¾at swich a lessoun sheweth.
Er deyntely drawe forÃ¾ / y do it on Èoure-selue.F.7.39: F alone reads Èoure-selue. Other witnesses have god hymselue.

A-geyn Ã¾e lawe of oure lord / & lyÈe on hem-selue.
/ [Â¶] Ãey spyttyn & spewen / & speke foule wordis.
& drynkyn / & dravelyn / & do men to gape.
Ãey lykne men / & lyÈen / Ã¾at leene hem no Èiftys
Ãey kunne no more menstralsy / ne musyk men to glade

Ne were here vile harlotriÈe / have god my trewÃ¾e.

But merthe with Menstralsy / a-mongis men nowt ys.
But Leccherye be leyÈd / in loselys talys.
& glotenyÈe & grete oÃ¾is / Ã¾at ys good merthe.
Â¶ But if Ã¾ey carpyn of crist / Ã¾ese clerkis to lewede.
At mete in Merthis / whan menstralis be stille.
Ãan talketalke [Ã¾ei] of Ã¾e trynnyte / a tale or tweyne.
& brynge a ballyd resoun forÃ¾ / & take bernard wittnesse.
& pitte forÃ¾ a qwestioun / & preve it for-soÃ¾e.
Ãus Ã¾ey dravele / at Ã¾e deyÈs / Ã¾e dyte to knowe.
& gnawe god with here gorge / whan here guttys be fulle.
Â¶ But Ã¾e kareful may criÈen / & mys-karyÈe at Ã¾e Èate.
BoÃ¾e for hunger & Ã¾urst / & for chele qwake.
Ãere ys non to nempne hym neer / his noyÈ to a-mende.
But hoen on hym / as an hound / & hote hym go his gate.
Lityl loveÃ¾ he Ã¾at lord / Ã¾at lente hym al Ã¾at blysse.
Ãat departeÃ¾ not with Ã¾e pore / a parcel whan hem nediÃ¾.
Ne were Mercy with mene men / more Ã¾an in ryche.
Manye mendynauntis meteles / myÈhte gon to bedde.
God is mychil in here gorgisF.7.68: Alpha is responsible for the plural form. / of Ã¾ese grete Maystris.
But a-mongis mene men / his mercy is / & hise werkys.
& so seyÃ¾ seyÃ¾seyÃ¾ / Ã¾e sawter book / y have seyn it ofte.

hi.hi: Ecce audiuimus eum in effrata ï ¡ inuenimus eumF.7.71: Alpha is responsible for eum in both occurrences in this line, though the reading is shared by Cr. Beta manuscripts have eam. in campis silue.

lg.l: Â¶ Clerkis & oÃ¾ereF.7.72: Alpha is responsible for omitting kynnes before men, though G omits it as well. men / carpen of goddis face.F.7.72: F's b-verse is unique. Bx reads "carpen of god faste."
& have hym myche in here mowÃ¾ / but mene men in herte.
But freris Ã¾o faytoures / have founde faire questionis.
To plese with prouhde men / sytthe Ã¾e pestylence.F.7.75: Alpha and most C manuscripts omit beta's and the A version's tyme after pestylence.
& prechen at poulis cros / for pure envyÈe of clerkis.
Ãat folk isis [not] fermed in Ã¾e feyÃ¾ / ne free of here goodis.
Ne sory for here synnys / so priÈde so hyÈe is waxe.F.7.78: Bx reads "so is pride woxen."
In Relygyon & in Ã¾is rewme / amongis ryche & pore.F.7.79: The scribe has written a large "VII" with flourishes in the top right margin to indicate the passus number.
Ãat prayeris have no powher / Ã¾ese pestylencys to lette.
For god is def / on Ã¾ese dayes / & deyÈneÃ¾ not vs to here. These lines are omitted from beta.
Ãe gystys for here giltys / he for-griynt hem alle.
& Èit no wrecche in Ã¾is world / is war be oÃ¾ir.
Ne for drede of Ã¾e deÃ¾ / with-draweth hem fram priÈde.
Ne plentevousere to Ã¾e pore / as pure charite wolde.
But in gaynesse & glotenye / Ã¾ei for-glutte hem-selue.
& breke no breed to Ã¾e beggere / as Ã¾e book hem techiÃ¾.

hi.hi: Frange esurienti panem tuum

lg.l: & Ã¾e more he wynnyÃ¾ / & welt / of welthis & rycchesse.

Euere as heF.7.90: Alpha is responsible for "Euere as he." Beta manuscripts have And. loondiÃ¾F.7.90: loondiÃ¾ is a nonce-word, apparently meaning "come into possession of land." Cf. OE (ge)landod and MED, s. v. londed ppl. adj. (1). The change began with a homeographic error in which <r> and <n> were confused. Bx reads "And lordeÃ¾ in londes ...." of londe / Ã¾e lasse good he deliÃ¾.
Â¶ But Thobye techiÃ¾ not so / takÃ¾ hede Èee ryche.
Hou Ã¾e byble book / of hym beriÃ¾ wytnesse.

hi.hi: Si tibi sit copia habundanter tribue.
Si autem exiguum ï ¡ illud impertire libenter stude.

lg.l: Â¶ Who-so haÃ¾ myche good / spende it manly seyÃ¾ thobye.
& who Ã¾at lytil weldiÃ¾ / rewle hym Ã¾ere-after.
For we have no lettre / of oure lyf / hou longe Ã¾at we dure.
Swyche lovely lessonys / lordis sholde here.
& how he myghte most meyghne manly[/] manly fyÈnde.
Nout to faren as a fythelere / for to fyÈnde festis.
& ben hoomly at here hows / & hatyn his owe.
Ful elenge is Ã¾e halle / ech day of Ã¾e wyke.
Ãere Ã¾e lord ne Ã¾e lady / ne lykiÃ¾ not in to sytte.
Nou haÃ¾ ech renke / a rewle / to etyn by hym-selue.
In a prive parlour / for pore mennys sake.
Or in a Chambre / with chymne / & leve his cheef halle.
Ãat was maad for men / melys to etyn Inne.
& al to sparen Ã¾e powndes / Ã¾at spendyn shal a-noÃ¾ir.
Â¶ I have herd ryÈt hyÈe men / etynge at Ã¾e table.
Carpid as Ã¾ey clerkis were / of crist & hise myghtis.

& leyÈd defawte on Ã¾e fadir / Ã¾at formedF.7.111: The <d> is perhaps a figment of my imagination (HND), for whatever the scribe attempted to squeeze in before the hole in the manuscript is unclear. vs alle.
& carpedyn a-geyn clerkis / swiche crabbedeF.7.112: An otiose curl is added to initial <c>. wordis.
Why ï ¡ wolde our saviour suffre / swich a worm in blysse.
Ãat by-gilede Ã¾e womman / & Ã¾e man after.
ÃorghÈ wiche wilis & wordis / Ã¾ei wentyn boÃ¾e to helle.
& alle here seed / for here synne / Ã¾e same deÃ¾ suffreden.
They lyen in here loore / Ã¾at Ã¾ese wordis meven.F.7.117: F's reading is unique. Bx reads "Here lyeÃ¾ youre lore Ã¾ise lordes gynneÃ¾ dispute."
For Ã¾e clerkys Ã¾us vus kennyÃ¾ / of cristes owne gospel.

l.note: F.7.119: F alone completes the quotation. Bx ends with "patris &c."

lg.l: Why sholde / Ã¾at nou be / for Ã¾e werkis of Adam.

F.7.121: A later hand inserted a pointing finger in the left margin. Oure soulis / Ragman rendeF.7.121: F's a-verse is unique. Bx reads "Roten and torende." The black underlining is by one of the later hands. / resoun wolde it neuere.

& make men in mysbeleve / Ã¾at mewsen on here wordis.

Suffre sory sathan / his seed to by-gyle.
But be-leveÃ¾ leelly / in holy chirche loore.
& praye god / of pardoun / & do penaunce in Ã¾i lyve.

If he lyve in Ã¾e lyÈueF.7.143: Kane-Donaldson read lyÈne. / Ã¾at longeÃ¾ to DowelF.7.143: The rubricating scribe here and in the immediately following lines in the words "Dowel ... Dobet ... Dobest" wrote over the original black ink so as almost to cover it entirely. We have treated these as rubrications rather than as touched in red.
I dar been his borwhÈF.7.144: Alpha is responsible for the omission of bolde before borwhÈ. / in Dobet komeÃ¾ he neuere.

He be-cam so confus / he cowhde vneÃ¾es loke.
& wex as deef / as dore-nail / & drow hym on syÈde.
& for no carpynge y cowhde / ne knelynge on grounde.
I myghte no[gete] no greyn / of hise grete wittys.
But al lawynge he lowtede / & lokede on dame stodye
In sygne / Ã¾at y sholde / be-sekne hire / of grace.
& whan y was war of his wille / to his wif gan y lowte.
& seyde Mercy Madame / Èoure man shal y worthe.
As longe as y lyve / boÃ¾e late & rathe.
&F.7.156: Alpha and nearly all C manuscripts have &. Beta and A manuscripts lack it. for to wirche Èoure wille / whil my lyf endureÃ¾.
So Èee kenne me kendely / to knowe what ys Dowel.
Â¶ For Ã¾y meeknesse man quod she / & for Ã¾y myÈlde speche.
I shal kenne Ã¾e to myn cosyn / Ã¾at klergye is named.

& she is sybbe Ã¾e[to] Ã¾e vij ars / ScriptureF.7.161: The rubricating scribe wrote over the original black ink so as almost to cover it entirely. We have treated it as rubrication rather than as touched in red. is hire name.F.7.161: Note the drawing in the right margin.
& Ã¾ey two / as y hope / & Ã¾ou do after my techynge.

& gladdere Ã¾an a gleman / Ã¾at gold gadred at festis.F.7.165: F's b-verse is unique. Bx reads "Ã¾at gold haÃ¾ to Èifte."

BoÃ¾e in wele & in woo / if Ã¾at Ã¾ou wilt leerne.

Fram loselys / & lythir speche / & lykerouse drynkis.

& telle hym Ã¾is tokne / how y sette hym to skole.
& also grete wel his wif / Ã¾at y wroot hire bookys.
& sette hire Sapiense[to] Sapiense / & to Ã¾e sawter glose.

& alle Ã¾e Musones in Musyk / y made hire to knowe.

& Aristotle & oÃ¾ireF.7.185: Beta manuscripts have mo after oÃ¾ire, but alpha and nearly all C manuscripts omit it. / to Argue / hem y tawhte.
& gramere for gerlys / y gart first wrytyn.
& beet hem with a baleyÈs / but Ã¾ei wolde leerne.
& to alle kenne craftys / y countrefetide toolys.

I lerned hem to levele be lyne / Ã¾ey y looke dymme.
Â¶ But Theologye Ã¾at teneÃ¾ me / ten skore tymes.

It is no sciense for-soÃ¾e / for to sawhtleF.7.194: Alpha is responsible for sawhtle "make peace, reconcile." Beta manuscripts and the A version have sotile "reflect upon, contemplate." The b-verse is revised in C. Inne.
A ful lethy Ã¾yng it were / if Ã¾at love ne were.
But for it is . led be love / y love it Ã¾e bettre.
For Ã¾ere Ã¾at love is ledere / ne lakkede neuere grace.

Ã¾erfore love Ã¾ou leelly / love / if Ã¾ou Ã¾ynke to dowel.F.7.198: F's reading is unique. Beta reads "Loke Ã¾ow loue lelly if Ã¾ee likeÃ¾ dowel." Alpha may have been corrupt, for R has "Loue Ã¾ow loue lelly if Ã¾ow thenke dowel."
& Dobet & Dobest / Ã¾ey ben of lovis kynne.

l.note: F.7.201: F omits "nec corde est fidus amicus."

hi.hi: Tu quoque fac simile / sic ars deluditur arte.

lg.l: Who-so gloseÃ¾ / as gyloures doon / goo fram here sawis
& so shalt Ã¾ou fals folk / & feyÃ¾les by-gyle.
Ãis is Catonys kennynge / to clergonys Ã¾at leerne.
But Theologye techiÃ¾ not so / who Ã¾at takÃ¾ heede.
He kenneÃ¾ vs Ã¾e contrarie / a-geyn Catonys wordis.
For he biddis vs be bretheryn / & bydde for oure enemyÈs.
& love hem / Ã¾at lyÈen on vs / & lene hemF.7.209: The scribe initially wrote leem, but overwrote the first two characters to make an <h>. whan hem nedeth.

lg.l: Poul prechede Ã¾e peple / Ã¾at parfyÈtnesse lovede.
To doon good / for goddis love / & gyve hem Ã¾at aske it.

& alle Ã¾at lakkeF.7.215: Alpha lacks beta's vs after lakke, an omission shared by Cr. or lyÈe on vs / oure lord biddis vs love hem.

Michi vindictam . & ego retribuam / god seide hym-selue.F.7.217: F smooths the inclusion of this tag by adding a b-verse not found in Bx which is a relict of the entirely revised b-verse in the preceding line.
An otiose curl appears over the <u> in selue.
For-Ã¾y ï ¡ loke Ã¾ou love as longe / as Ã¾ou lengyst heere.

GeometriÈe & Geomesye / is gynful of spechis.
Who Ã¾ynkiÃ¾ wirche with Ã¾o two / he thryviÃ¾ ful late.
For sorceryÈe is Ã¾e souereyn sekt / Ã¾at to Ã¾o sciencis longiÃ¾.

Experimentis & AlkenemyÈe / Ã¾e peple to disseyve.
If Ã¾ou Ã¾ynke to dowel / deyle Ã¾ou Ã¾er-with neuere.
& alle Ã¾ese sciencis y my-selue / y-sotilde & ordeynede
& fond hem formest / folk to disseyve.
Now telle Clergye Ã¾ese toknys / & to scripture after.

hi.hi: I
te vos in vineam meam ï ¡ & quod iustum fuerit . dabitur vobis.

l.note: F.7.497: F alone completes the quotation. Bx's text ends with "vineam meam."

lg.l: Â¶ Ãanne scripture skornede me / & a skele me tolde.

For me lakkede latyn / lyght by me heF.7.499: he: Manuscripts WHmCrLM read she; others omit the pronoun as do Kane and Donaldson. An unlikely form of the feminine nominative singular in this scribe's dialect, it is here a relict from alpha which in turn reflects Langland's own usage. See F14.156 for an instance in which RF have he for "she" and where alliteration shows that the reading with an "h-" form of the pronoun is original. Cf. F8.104, where F uses he to refer to Scripture. See also M. L. Samuels, "Dialect and Grammar," in A Companion to Piers Plowman, ed. John A. Alford (Berkeley and Los Angeles: U of California P, 1988), p. 109. sette.
& seyde multi multa sciunt . & seipsos nesciunt.
Ão for sorwe y wepte / & was wrothÈ of hire speche.
& of myn wynkynge y a-wook / & wondrede Ã¾anne These six lines appear only in F.
